channel.title: Return of the Wilderness
channel.description:
This week’s update introduces Bounty Hunter ‘Wilderness-only’ PvP worlds (or ‘Bounty Worlds’). Our aim was to get something that feels as close to the original Wilderness as we can manage, and to add another thrill with the Bounty Hunter mechanic. The new worlds are limited to the Wilderness, and use the old ‘who can attack who’ levels. Bounty Worlds are basically a mix of 3 previous PvP games. It has the best bits we can reuse from Bounty Hunter, PvP worlds, and the old Wilderness. In short, we’ve increased the chance to get your opponent’s items and we added the thrill of hunting a bounty within the Wilderness while surrounded by hundreds of potential PKers. Here’s how it works: You can attack anyone within the level range determined by the Wilderness level, starting with 1 just above Edgeville to 56 at the top of the map. If you kill someone who isn’t your bounty target, it is considered a ‘rogue kill’. There is no penalty for rogue kills any more. It will add 1 to your ‘rogue kills’ highscore, and you will get a drop based on the ‘drop potential’ mechanic from PvP worlds (see here for more details). We have, however, made it so that, when drop potential is converted to items, it is 3 times more likely to give you items your target was carrying, as opposed to generated items. The average size of the rewards is based on your drop potential the same as in PvP worlds. After you have spent 30 minutes in a dangerous area on a Bounty World, the system will start looking for suitable ‘bounty targets’ for you. After 60 minutes, the chance of being assigned a target increases further. (Note: this doesn’t have to be all in one go, and isn’t reset by leaving.) Your target will always be a similar level to you. To make things even more interesting, you will also be their target! If you kill your target, it will add 1 to your ‘bounty kills’ highscore, and you will receive a generous boost to your drop: the average size of these drops is boosted by an extra hour of drop potential (just as if you’d spent an hour in a hot zone), on top of the drop you would receive normally. In addition to this, we’ve made it more likely that you’ll get items from your opponent’s actual inventory for killing your target – this also applies to rogue kills and in normal PvP worlds, but at a lower rate. To make sure you have a chance of getting to the rewards, there are a couple of extra rules. Firstly, if your bounty target is fighting someone else in a single-way combat area, you will be able to attack your target, and their original foe will be locked out. Secondly, if you are fighting your enemy but do not inflict enough damage to count as the ‘hero’ (in the same way as drops are awarded when fighting monsters), your target will remain your target. Basically, your bounty target will remain your bounty target until one of you kills the other, or one of you leaves the Wilderness for more than ten minutes. It isn’t all about the rewards, of course: it’s also about the thrill of trying to hunt someone down in an environment where the levels are well-matched. That’s why we brought back the old Wilderness levels, and restricted the action to the old Wilderness area. You can only fight in the Wilderness, and the only other area available is Edgeville, where you can restock and prepare for battle. You have to be in one of those areas before you can log into a Bounty World. So, head to Edgeville, switch to a Bounty World, and see if you can work your way up the Rogue/Bounty Hunter highscore tables. Andrew Lead Developer In Other News… Thirsty adventurers should head to the poll to take part in our latest vote: Guaranteed Content – Name a Pub. We have made a shortlist of your very best pub suggestions, and now we need you decide which one is your favourite. The winning idea will be added to the game in the coming months. You can find the poll under the 'Community' drop-down tab above. Similar to the changes we made to the way PvP worlds work to prevent people from using fun weapons or low-level spells, we have updated the system to detect other ways of fighting without taking any risks. Now, if you see anyone in single-way combat who is fighting without taking any apparent damage over an extended period of time, you can jump in and teach them how fighting works. The lilies of the valley have finished blooming, and have been removed from the game. Any you might have had lying around have been whisked away. Leprechauns can now convert clean herbs to banknotes for you. Previously, if you'd accidentally cleaned the herb, the leprechaun wouldn't accept the herb. The in-game skill guides now link to an appropriate page in the Game Guide if you wish to find out more information.
Interesting. I'm going to need to start botting again.

item.title: Return of the Wilderness
item.dc:creator: @pk3r_john pk3r john
item.description:
@pk3r_john wrote:

It looks good and I might come back, dunno if I should. The training takes a shitload of time and it might not be worth it.
Although, I noticed that the title on the update said “PVP drops”. This hints at something suspicious and it could be full drops again.

Read full topic

item.title: Return of the Wilderness
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

fashox:

what pisses me off is i kill one person, and as im picking up the loot, another person comes along and finishes me off… fucking weak bitches…

It’s called pjing. I do it all the time, because there’s good (and easy) loot involved. You’ll find that most people that pj fights are like single->multi lurers; they have an account purpose built for combat, and they’re doing it for kicks. If I was to prioritise, I’d say I do it for kicks, closely followed by loot. The whining that occurs will always be fun to laugh at.

It certainly doesn’t make them weak.

Read full topic

item.title: Return of the Wilderness
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I’ve welcomed it as a very reasonable attempt at restoring the wilderness as a PVP zone. Personally I only pk in f2p worlds when soloing, as pking solo on p2p is nothing but a mistake (at least for a ranger or mage).

Here’s a sample of my kills thus far:
This one was a pilejump, but I don’t care.

Deathmatch. This guy was a good sport. The helm was mine; we no armoured. Nothing too special about the guy; his stats were actually quite inferior to mine, but then he asked for the fight. :rolleyes:

Can’t remember if this was declared a deathmatch, but he ended up dead anyway. He had 69 attack, 99 strength. We were both wearing robes for the fight, but yeah. 82 defence is a winning level.

This was a death match. This guy was 80 attack, 99 strength, probably would have had 20 - 40 defence as well. Quite a good fight, although complaining about someone sitting on 30 health kinda makes you a pussy.

With all of that aside, it’s a lot of fun. You can’t teleport on these worlds, so that’s a non-issue now. The downside is that bind is still the only f2p hold spell you can employ, and it’s not really worth the inventory space. I’m hoping they make snare usable on f2p PVP worlds, because it would be a nice boost to the usability of magic.

EDIT: To put the above kills in perspective, here’s a pic of my stats. Obviously I didn’t get all of the loot above playing on a level 60 account.

Read full topic

item.title: Return of the Wilderness
item.dc:creator: @Tenac Tenac
item.description:
@Tenac wrote:

Jagex needs to stop getting their panties in a bunch and learn that the game was the best before they started removing all freedom to the players because of RWT. I will never understand what they lost due to RWT or how it affected them other than more members accounts, but w/e, it’s their problem that they are handling the wrong way I think.

item.title: Return of the Wilderness
item.dc:creator: @cooper cooper
item.description:
@cooper wrote:

[quote="ExiledScape, post:14, topic:277564"][quote author=Rich link=topic=366442.msg2779008#msg2779008 date=1241665259]

I’m lvl 131.

I’ve tried the new pvp.

It’s shit.

Many stupid one itemers.

Crappy drop system.

It’s a piss load of fuck.

Are you retarded?

The drop system in the new BH PvP has a higher drop potential then it does in PvP worlds, and one itemers have been around since the old wilderness.

There will be less of them when the hype dies down.

I am interested in seeing how populated these worlds will be and the effect they will have on the population of the regular pvp worlds.

When it was first released they only had two worlds for BH PvP and both were full to capacity in less then 10 minutes of the update, they ended up having to release like 4 or 5 more worlds for it. Although, It will be interesting to see how it ends up in the next few days/weeks after the hype dies down.
[/quote]

Oh really? >_>

Well i just heard it isn’t drop potential anymore.

You get 75% of what your opponent had…[/quote]

If you kill your target, it will add 1 to your ‘bounty kills’ highscore, and you will receive a generous boost to your drop: the average size of these drops is boosted by an extra hour of drop potential (just as if you’d spent an hour in a hot zone), on top of the drop you would receive normally. In addition to this, we’ve made it more likely that you’ll get items from your opponent’s actual inventory for killing your target – this also applies to rogue kills and in normal PvP worlds, but at a lower rate. ... We have, however, made it so that, when drop potential is converted to items, it is 3 times more likely to give you items your target was carrying, as opposed to generated items. The average size of the rewards is based on your drop potential the same as in PvP worlds.
You/your source misinterpreted the article.

Read full topic

item.title: Return of the Wilderness
item.dc:creator: @cooper cooper
item.description:
@cooper wrote:

This week’s update introduces Bounty Hunter ‘Wilderness-only’ PvP worlds (or ‘Bounty Worlds’). Our aim was to get something that feels as close to the original Wilderness as we can manage, and to add another thrill with the Bounty Hunter mechanic. The new worlds are limited to the Wilderness, and use the old ‘who can attack who’ levels.

Bounty Worlds are basically a mix of 3 previous PvP games. It has the best bits we can reuse from Bounty Hunter, PvP worlds, and the old Wilderness. In short, we’ve increased the chance to get your opponent’s items and we added the thrill of hunting a bounty within the Wilderness while surrounded by hundreds of potential PKers.

Here’s how it works:

You can attack anyone within the level range determined by the Wilderness level, starting with 1 just above Edgeville to 56 at the top of the map. If you kill someone who isn’t your bounty target, it is considered a ‘rogue kill’. There is no penalty for rogue kills any more. It will add 1 to your ‘rogue kills’ highscore, and you will get a drop based on the ‘drop potential’ mechanic from PvP worlds (see here for more details). We have, however, made it so that, when drop potential is converted to items, it is 3 times more likely to give you items your target was carrying, as opposed to generated items. The average size of the rewards is based on your drop potential the same as in PvP worlds.

After you have spent 30 minutes in a dangerous area on a Bounty World, the system will start looking for suitable ‘bounty targets’ for you. After 60 minutes, the chance of being assigned a target increases further. (Note: this doesn’t have to be all in one go, and isn’t reset by leaving.) Your target will always be a similar level to you. To make things even more interesting, you will also be their target! If you kill your target, it will add 1 to your ‘bounty kills’ highscore, and you will receive a generous boost to your drop: the average size of these drops is boosted by an extra hour of drop potential (just as if you’d spent an hour in a hot zone), on top of the drop you would receive normally. In addition to this, we’ve made it more likely that you’ll get items from your opponent’s actual inventory for killing your target – this also applies to rogue kills and in normal PvP worlds, but at a lower rate.

To make sure you have a chance of getting to the rewards, there are a couple of extra rules. Firstly, if your bounty target is fighting someone else in a single-way combat area, you will be able to attack your target, and their original foe will be locked out. Secondly, if you are fighting your enemy but do not inflict enough damage to count as the ‘hero’ (in the same way as drops are awarded when fighting monsters), your target will remain your target. Basically, your bounty target will remain your bounty target until one of you kills the other, or one of you leaves the Wilderness for more than ten minutes.

It isn’t all about the rewards, of course: it’s also about the thrill of trying to hunt someone down in an environment where the levels are well-matched. That’s why we brought back the old Wilderness levels, and restricted the action to the old Wilderness area. You can only fight in the Wilderness, and the only other area available is Edgeville, where you can restock and prepare for battle. You have to be in one of those areas before you can log into a Bounty World. So, head to Edgeville, switch to a Bounty World, and see if you can work your way up the Rogue/Bounty Hunter highscore tables.

Andrew
Lead Developer

In Other News…

Thirsty adventurers should head to the poll to take part in our latest vote: Guaranteed Content – Name a Pub. We have made a shortlist of your very best pub suggestions, and now we need you decide which one is your favourite. The winning idea will be added to the game in the coming months. You can find the poll under the ‘Community’ drop-down tab above.

Similar to the changes we made to the way PvP worlds work to prevent people from using fun weapons or low-level spells, we have updated the system to detect other ways of fighting without taking any risks. Now, if you see anyone in single-way combat who is fighting without taking any apparent damage over an extended period of time, you can jump in and teach them how fighting works.

The lilies of the valley have finished blooming, and have been removed from the game. Any you might have had lying around have been whisked away.

Leprechauns can now convert clean herbs to banknotes for you. Previously, if you’d accidentally cleaned the herb, the leprechaun wouldn’t accept the herb.

The in-game skill guides now link to an appropriate page in the Game Guide if you wish to find out more information.


Interesting. I’m going to need to start botting again.

Read full topic
